content.webTitle: Stacey Dooley: The Young and Homeless review – a perilous tale of life on the streets

fields.headline: Stacey Dooley: The Young and Homeless review – a perilous tale of life on the streets
fields.bodyText: Josh has been working since his 16th birthday. He is now 18 and a grade-three mechanic. Beyond that, he is funny, generous, gentle and good-looking, and he ought to have it made. But his mum threw him out earlier this year (“Decided her boyfriend was better than I am, basically”), blocked him on her phone and told the council, when they went round to plead for her to take her son back in, that there was no chance of him returning. So, he went to Blackpool to look for work. He found work – a zero-hours contract at a fast-food place – but he also found himself part of the hidden homeless. What began as sofa surfing gradually gave way to shelters and nights on the street. His boss offers to pay for a B&B when his shifts finish too late for him to get a shelter (you have to be there by 7pm to have a chance of a place), but he refuses to take her up on it. And – because there are girls who will have to stay on the streets if he takes up a bed (there are just eight in the Streetlife shelter, the only one in town that specifically supports young homeless people) – he stays out instead. He is one of the tens upon tens of thousands – think of that, tens upon tens of thousands – of 16-to-24-year-olds who experience some form of homelessness every year, and one of a handful followed for nine months by Stacey Dooley for The Young and Homeless (BBC One), a film made in conjunction with Children in Need. The other young people include Shelby and Cat, who left unhappy homes and the care system and ended up on the sofas of friends, then on the streets of Manchester. Cat lives in a tent under a railway arch and has already sunk deep within herself. Until recently, she had kept hold of her job – the resilience and determination of everyone Dooley speaks to makes you want to bang austerity politicians’ heads off cobbles until they start shitting money – but now she just can’t manage. “I think,” she says, amid piles of sleeping bags, crisp packets and crack pipes that have accumulated under the arches over the years, “it makes you depressed a little bit. I get down. I don’t want to get out of bed.” Shelby’s eyes look brighter, but perhaps this is just what perpetual vigilance looks like. She is sleeping alone on a sofa in someone’s back garden and “there’s quite a lot of crime going on these days”, she says. “Girls getting groomed and that. There’s an art to it, apparently. They can twist your mind and just make it feel like it’s your fault.” Has she ever been approached by them, asks Dooley. “Not recently,” is the answer. “I’ve been through stuff before, so I’m quite clever with stuff like that. I can spot it.” Shelby made her first suicide attempt at 12. Dooley – an excellent presenter, anyway – is the natural and ideal choice here. Her interviewees need and deserve her supportive, warm presence, and she is close enough in age and attitude to tread where older reporters might hesitate to go. And viewers need her willingness between interviews to share her thoughts on screen. “When I was 18,” she remembers, “I was working at Luton airport and spending all my money on going out and buying tops. I had no fears, no responsibilities … They’re so streetwise,” she says of her subjects. “But they also seem like babies.” And they do. Neglected, struggling, impossibly brave, possibly doomed babies, older than we will ever be. There are some happy endings, within the limited parameters of their stories. Cat finds a hostel that provides support, and life comes back into her face. With the help of other charities, Josh surmounts the obstacles of being over 18 and without a connection to Blackpool to become a priority case for the council, and manages to get a private rental flat. He will be on housing benefit at first, but he has two jobs and is sure – and please, God, let this be the voice of his hard-won experience and not his beautiful, dangerous, youthful optimism – he will soon be able to pay the rent himself and start to build a life. There’s no definitive word on Shelby. A law was passed in April requiring councils to make housing all young people without homes a priority. Centrepoint estimates they need an extra £10m to be able to do such a thing. I guess Shelby – and tens upon tens of thousands of her fellow sufferers – are still waiting.
